DOC.HEAD: Shots Fired at U.S. Library in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Three armed men opened fire on the U.S. Information Service library in Davao City on Sunday, shattering windows but causing no injuries, police reported. Sgt. Rommel Moya said the gunmen escaped after shooting from a speeding car about 1:15 p.m. The library was closed at the time, Moya said. There was no indication who was responsible for the shooting. Communist rebels operate in Davao City, 600 miles southeast of Manila. But government troops have been on alert in the Davao area because of reports that military mutineers who tried to topple President Corazon Aquino earlier this month were planning attacks in the Davao area. The mutineers were angered when U.S. warplanes flew air cover missions to support government forces Dec. 1, the first day of the failed coup. Although they did not fire, the U.S. jets helped turn the tide in the battle. The military said Saturday that five private shooting clubs associated with the son of Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, were involved in the failed coup. The Philippine Constabulary said about 100 civilian members of the clubs were identified through photographs and videotapes as having fought alongside military mutineers who launched the coup attempt. The shooting clubs are part of the Philippine Tactical Shooting Association, an umbrella organization headed by Juan ``Jackie'' Ponce Enrile Jr., son of the former defense minister and lone opposition member of the Senate, the constabulary said. The statement did not specifically name the younger Enrile as among those members taking part in the coup attempt. The elder Enrile has denied involvement in the coup attempt, believed to have been led by a clique of officers associated with him when he served as Mrs. Aquino's defense chief. Enrile was fired in November 1986 after a failed coup by his followers.
